data: Epigrafi funerarie greche e latine di Taormina
Francesco Muscolino, «Epigrafi funerarie greche e latine di Taormina», Rivista di Archeologia Cristiana 87–88 (2012 2011): 209–48
Regular even letters with simple serifs, and mixture of interpunctuation; A without crossbar.
later 1st century CE or early 2nd century CE
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J.Prag 2017-07-21

Funerary inscription for Publius Edusius Basilides
Four lines of Latin, first line cnetred, lines 2-4 with consistent left margin; guidelines visible top and bottom of each line.
Deep cut letters simple serifs, simply cut, moderate width module.

Letters with a fluid / curving stroke, extensions to strokes and/or serirfs, R is open.

later Roman, but not certain whether Christian or Pagan (Ferrua)

2[Ῥ]ῶσκις Τρόφ[ιμος]
3[---] ἔζησεν ἔτη [---]
six lines of Greek letters with a consistent left margin, and a slight gap between lines 1-3 and lines 4-6.
Simply cut letters without serifs. Quadrate epsilon, lunate quadrate sigma, rhomboid omega, mu with very short middle strokes. Use of stigma in numerals, and interpuncts to separate numerals.

Three lines of Greek letters filling the stone from the top
Crude letters, often cut with a shallow square channel. Quadrate and lunate epsilon.

Monument with cornice bearing the name Chrysis
The text in the fourth panel runs from bottom to top and appears to be written retrograde.
Neat regular letters, with quadrate lunate sigma.
monument with cornice bearing the name chrysis

section b
Col. 4
 1((Χρυσίς))
Four lines of Greek letters, starting consistently against the left margin of the stone.

Deeply incised, slightly irregular angular letters: Alpha with downward left-sloping cross-bar; quadrate epsilon; quadrate lunate epsilon; quadrate cursive omega, use of supraline for abbreviation marker.
